_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: Title V Air Pollution Control Permit to Operate Air Emissions Equipment.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

A. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

Inter-Pac, Inc. (Inter-Pac) is a specialty foam manufacturing facility which produces polyethylene (PE) foam, and structural polystyrene (SPS) Foam located in Tupelo, Mississippi. The PE foam manufacturing process also includes a laminated PE foam process. A Title V Permit Application renewal was submitted to Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality in January 2011.

Polyethylene foam or "PE" foam is a plastic product made of polyethylene resin mixed with reclaimed product and additives, extrusion of the mixed resin through a highly specialized extruder; adding a liquid blowing agent (Isobutane), then cooling the material and forcing it through a die. The finished product is produced in variety of colors, thicknesses, and densities. The Isobutane is stored at the tank storage area in one (1) 7,000 gallon and two (2) 6,000 gallon storage tanks with a combined storage capacity of 19,000 gallons which equates to 89,177 pounds of Isobutane.

The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to processes storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is isobutane in excess of 10,000 pounds which is used as a blowing agent in the manufacturing process.

After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process. Based on the facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program Level 3 of the RMP regulations.

B.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Inter-Pac is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of Isobutane is in the written Risk Management Prog

ram. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 

C. Hazard Assessment

The RMP requires Inter-Pac to evaluate the maximum potentially affected area for accidents involving Isobutane for worst case release scenario and an alternative scenario.

The worst case release is highly improbable since it involves the combination of a certain set of conditions for a large release of the chemical without any employee intervention. The assumptions for the worst-case analysis are very conservative. The endpoints specified for regulated flammable substances are intended to be protective of the general public. The distance to the endpoint estimated under worst-case conditions should not be considered an area in which the public would likely be in danger; instead, it is intended to provide an estimate of the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic accident. EPA intends the estimated distances to provide a basis for discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders, and the public, rather a basis for any specific actions.

A release from the 7,000 gallon storage tank has been identified as the worst-case release and was considered in the hazard assessment. The 7,000 gallons of Isobutane equates to approximately 32,833 lbs of Isobutane. The tanks are surrounded by secondary containment which would fully contain a spill from a single tank. Thereby reducing the evaporation rate of the spill.

The impact distance from the worst-case scenario has been estimated using EPA's RMPcomp Model. The impact distance from the RMPcomp Model results in an impact distance of 0.3 miles. The impact distance extends beyond the facility property.

The alternative scenario is an event more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and is a more realistic accident scenario. Inter-Pac has determined that appropriate alternative sc

enario for the facility is a process piping release from the process line carrying Isobutane from the tank to the pump room. The leak would release approximately 1,599 lbs of Isobutane. The RMPcomp Method estimates a distance to the endpoint of 0.05 mile for the alternative release scenario.

D. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Process Safety Information: Inter-Pac will complete a compilation of written safety information to be used in conducting the process hazard analysis (PHA). The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane System. The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane system.

Process Hazard Analysis: Inter-Pac will update and re-validate the PHA as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The PHA was conducted using  the "What IF" methodology, which is one of the methodologies specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including one member who has expertise in the Isobutane system and a member knowledgeable in the specified PHA methodology. A system was established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operation, maintenance and other employees who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

Operating Procedures: Inter-Pac has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where Isobutane is utilized. These written operating procedures will be consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and h

ealth considerations, and safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the Isobutane system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. Inter-Pac will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate. Inter-Pac will develop and implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the Inter-Pac facility.

Training: Inter-Pac will provide training for each employee associated with the Isobutane system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.67. Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. Inter-Pac documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity: Inter-Pac will develop a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the Isobutane system (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.

Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the Isobutane system components receives training at least every three (3) years or more often if necessary.
Management of Change: Inter-Pac will establish and implement written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures and changes to Inter-Pac that effect the Isobutane system. These procedures assure that appropriate considerations are addressed prior to any change. Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are informed of, and trained

in, the change prior to start-up of the system. If a change results in the change in the process safety information, operation procedures, or practices, they will be updated accordingly.

Pre-Start-up Safety Review: Inter-Pac will perform a Pre-Start-up Safety Review according to 40 CFR 68.67 when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information, equipment, operating procedures or practices.
Compliance Audits: Inter-Pac will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least one employee knowledgeable in the Isobutane system. A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. Inter-Pac will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained.

Incident Investigation: Inter-Pac will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Isobutane. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. A report will be prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and Inter-Pac will promptly address and resolve the incident findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions will be documented. Incident investigation reports will be retained for five (5) years.

Employee Participation: Inter-Pac will develop a written plan of action regarding employee participation. The facility will consult with employees on the conduct and development of process hazard analysis and other elements of the system management. Inter-Pac will provide em

ployee access to hazard analysis and to all other information required to be developed under 40 CFR Part 68.

Hot Work Permit: Inter-Pac will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the Isobutane system.

Contractors: Inter-Pac when selecting a contractor will obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract owner or operator's safety performance and programs. Inter-Pac will inform the contract owner or operator of the known release hazards related to the contractor's work and the Isobutane system. Inter-Pac will explain to the contract owner or operator of, the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan. Inter-Pac will periodically evaluate the performance of the contract owner or operator in fulfilling their obligations as specified below.

Contract owners or operators will assure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform their job. Contract owners or operators and Inter-Pac will assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential release hazard related to their job and the Isobutane system and the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.

E. Five-year Accident History

Although, Inter-Pac has not had an accidental release of Isobutane that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site or any known off-site, death, injuries evacuations, sheltering in place, property, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five (5) years, a release did occur on October 2009. An estimated 26,253 lbs of Isobutane was released over an undetermined amount of time from Friday October 16 to Monday October 19, 2009. An investigation of the incident revealed a faulty seal on the Corken Regenerative Turbine pump that lead to the release of Isobutane. There were no deaths, injuries or significant property damage on-site, or any known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage du

e to this release. The Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality was notified of the release on October 19, 2009. A copy of the Notification letter is provided in Appendix R of the RMP plan.

F. Emergency Response Program

Inter-Pac will develop and implement an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. This program includes the following elements: 
1. An emergency response plan, which is maintained on site and contains at least the 
   following elements:
a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies;
b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to 
   accidental human exposures; and
c. Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of 
   Isobutane.
2. Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection.
3. Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and
4. Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to  
   reflect changes at Inter-Pac and ensure that employees are informed of changes.
G. Planned Changes to Improve Safety.

In an attempt to insure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training concerning this safety and environmental program and others will be conducted annually. This program requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the Isobutane system. Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires Inter-Pac to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.
